description: Dive into "Architectural Wonders of Varanasi" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Architectural Wonders of Varanasi

places.generalDescription: Dashashwamedh Ghat is a vibrant and bustling riverside step leading down to the Ganges River, where daily religious rituals take place. It's known as one of the most lively ghats in the town and offers a spiritual experience.

sources.snippet: The most important attraction of Varanasi ‚Äì Ganga aarti can be witnessed on the Dashashwamedh Ghat daily at dusk. It is considered as the most spectacular ghat filled with tourists, monks, Men, Women, and children celebrating the water. It symbolizes that Varanasi is not only about cremation and death, it is also about celebrating the colorful journey of life.
sources.shortName: Architecture of Indian Cities: Varanasi- Beyond being the spiritual Capital of India - RTF

places.name: Dashashwamedh Ghat

reviews.text:
My visit to Dashashwamedh Ghat in Varanasi was nothing short of magical. This is the heart of spiritual India, especially during the famous Ganga Aarti that takes place every evening. The atmosphere is electric - chants, bells, and the sight of hundreds of lamps illuminating the river create an experience that words can hardly capture.

However, it's important to plan ahead! The ghat gets extremely crowded, with devotees and tourists filling every inch of space. I would highly recommend reaching by 4 PM if you want a front-level seat. After that, it becomes almost impossible to even find a place to stand. Despite the rush, witnessing the Ganga Aarti up close is absolutely worth every bit of effort.

The energy, the devotion, and the stunning views of the Ganges under the evening sky make it an unforgettable memory. If you truly want to feel the soul of Varanasi, Dashashwamedh Ghat is the place to be.

This is the main ghat of Varanasi and definitely the busiest spot along the Ganges. It's absolutely bustling with activity throughout the day. Early mornings bring crowds of people gathering to watch the beautiful sunrise over the river, while evenings are packed with visitors coming to witness the mesmerizing aarti puja ceremony. The energy here is incredible. you'll find locals and tourists alike all mixed together, creating this wonderful, chaotic atmosphere that feels so authentically Varanasi

Dashashwamedh Ghat is undoubtedly one of the most iconic and spiritually significant places in Varanasi. Set along the banks of the sacred Ganga, the ghat offers a deeply peaceful experience-especially during the early mornings or late nights when the crowds are thinner. The calmness of the river, the chanting of mantras in the background, and the occasional ring of temple bells together create a truly serene atmosphere that is difficult to put into words.

One of the main highlights here is the Ganga Aarti, which takes place every evening around sunset. It's a grand, mesmerizing ritual performed by priests with synchronized movements, conch shells, and flaming lamps. The entire event is visually stunning and spiritually moving. However, it does get extremely crowded during the Aarti, so it's a good idea to arrive early if you want a decent spot to watch. Alternatively, watching it from a boat offers a less congested and equally beautiful perspective.

Speaking of boats, rides are easily available and highly recommended-especially during sunrise or sunset. A boat ride along the ghats allows you to witness the full stretch of Varanasi's sacred riverfront, dotted with temples, historic structures, and daily life unfolding in its rawest form. It's a peaceful, reflective experience that complements the energy of the ghat itself.

Another positive point is the cleanliness. Compared to some other ghats, Dashashwamedh is relatively well-maintained, especially considering the huge number of visitors it attracts daily. Authorities and volunteers seem to make a good effort to keep the place tidy, though peak hours do bring some inevitable crowd-related littering.

In summary, Dashashwamedh Ghat is a must-visit if you're in Varanasi-not just for its religious significance, but for the unique energy it offers. Whether you're a spiritual seeker, a culture lover, or simply someone looking to experience the soul of the city, this ghat captures it all. Just be prepared for crowds during popular times and plan accordingly for the best experience.

places.address: Dashashwamedh Ghat Rd, Ghats of Varanasi, Godowlia, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

places.generalDescription: Shri Kashi Vishwanath Temple is a renowned riverside temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, featuring an impressive 18th-century gold-plated spire and a sacred well. It's also the only Jyotirlinga in Uttar Pradesh.

sources.snippet: The Kashi Vishwanath Mandir temple is the most recognized in Varanasi and is located on the west bank of the Ganges. It is considered the spiritual center for millions of Hindus and pilgrims from all over the world. The current form of the temple was built in 1780, although it underwent multiple reforms and extensions in subsequent years.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Varanasi for Travelling Architect

sources.snippet: The city's oldest temples, such as the Kashi Vishwanath Temple, feature classic Hindu architectural elements such as towering spires, intricate carvings, and elaborate mandapas (pillared halls). These structures pay homage to the rich cultural and religious heritage of Varanasi, embodying timeless principles of spirituality and devotion.
sources.shortName: Secrets of Ancient Varanasi Architecture: Temples, Ghats, and Monuments

sources.snippet: It is a belief that people travel here from far off places to finally end their lives, in the Karvat Kashi temple located in the vicinity of the Vishwanath temple complex. However, in recent times the term Karvat Kashi has been used popularly to describe a bent temple (Karvat, meaning bent) located on the Ghats.
sources.shortName: Architecture of Kashi | Architecture of Varanasi

places.name: Shri Kashi Vishwanath Temple

reviews.text:
The Shri Kashi Vishwanath Temple is not just a sacred site - it's the spiritual heartbeat of Varanasi, and one of the most powerful places I've ever visited. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, the temple radiates an aura that's difficult to put into words but deeply felt the moment you step inside the complex.

Despite the high footfall of devotees and tight security, everything is incredibly well-organized. The temple staff and volunteers guide you with patience and respect, ensuring everyone gets their darshan peacefully. The architecture itself is a beautiful blend of tradition and majesty - the golden spire gleams against the sky, a symbol of Varanasi's eternal spirit.

What struck me most was the intensity of devotion. Standing in front of the Jyotirlinga, with chants of ‚ÄúHar Har Mahadev‚Äù filling the air, I felt a rare kind of stillness - a connection with something far beyond the physical. Whether you're deeply religious or just spiritually curious, the energy inside the sanctum is palpable.

Early morning visits are especially powerful - the aarti, the sound of bells, and the scent of sandalwood and incense create a soul-stirring atmosphere. The newly developed Kashi Vishwanath Corridor has beautifully transformed the area around the temple - making it more spacious, accessible, and visually stunning while retaining its sacred vibe.

There are small shrines and courtyards throughout the complex that are worth exploring, each with its own story and significance. Don't miss spending a few quiet moments at the Ganga-facing side of the corridor - it's peaceful and offers an incredible view of the river.

This temple is not just a destination - it's a spiritual moment, a living tradition, and a place where the past, present, and divine converge. Visiting Kashi Vishwanath is more than a religious journey - it's an emotional, cultural, and soulful experience.

Our family visit to Kashi Vishwanath Temple was a truly divine experience. The spiritual energy, the chanting of mantras, and the sacred atmosphere filled our hearts with peace. The temple is beautifully maintained, and the darshan was smooth despite the crowd. Walking through the vibrant streets of Kashi with family made it even more special. A must visit for anyone seeking blessings and inner calm. Truly unforgettable moments in the heart of Varanasi.

One of the most sacred places in Hinduism. One of the 12 divine jyotirlingas. The main temple premises are very neat and clean and very well maintained. The whole place is managed very efficiently despite a huge tourist footfall. Divine experience and a must visit place in lifetime.

places.address: Lahori Tola, Varanasi, Domari, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

places.generalDescription: Banaras Hindu University (BHU) is a sprawling residential university located on the banks of the Ganges River. The campus covers a vast 5km area and features a blend of architectural splendor and academic excellence. Visitors can explore historic buildings, lush gardens, and majestic structures that reflect a mix of classical and colonial architecture.

sources.snippet: Its campus is in the shape of a semicircle with intersecting radial streets. It is five and a half kilometers square long and is consequently one of the largest universities in India. Its interest for the visitor, in addition to the aforementioned museum, lies in the pavilions and their extraordinary architectural value.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Varanasi for Travelling Architect

places.name: Banaras Hindu University

reviews.text:
No words to describe this palace,this place is next level because tourist destinations or many reason.
I spend almost 45 min here ,BHU IS in 16 sq km, therefore you have 1 day full to detailed or describe to know everything about this place.Here 1 famous temple is also available where foreigner is come from every country to visit and explore here.

I felt a little bit concerned about my safety while visiting this university since it's an open university which makes it heavily crowded not only with people but also with heavy traffic. The authorities of the BHU campus should look into this matter with severity and try either to make the situation manageable or to take preemptive actions to regulate the entry of the foreign people from outside with vehicles!!

One of the world's largest University in terms of its area.
A very soothing and sight seeing campus.
It's the Asia's greenest campus containing university.
A wonderful entrance and very good education in any field.
Even though a very beautiful temple known as 'The Vishwanath temple' is there. You will find everything here if you visit.

places.generalDescription: Shri Satyanarayan Tulsi Manas Mandir in Varanasi is a grand Hindu temple made of white marble, featuring beautiful gardens and detailed engravings. It's situated in the Tulsi Ghat area and pays homage to Lord Rama. The temple is known for its peaceful ambiance and elaborate marble carvings depicting stories from Ramcharitmanas, a renowned Hindu epic poem.

sources.snippet: Almost two hundred years after the construction of Kashi Vishwanath or Annapurna Temple, the Tulsi Manas temple was completed in the year 1964. There is a consensus that this temple stands on the original site where Goswami Tulsidas wrote the famous Ramcharitmanas. For this reason, we will find on the walls covered in marble, both in the temple and in the extraordinary surrounding gardens, verses of the said epic poem composed in the 16th century.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Varanasi for Travelling Architect

places.name: Shri Satyanarayan Tulsi Manas Mandir, Varanasi

reviews.text: Tulsi Manas Mandir is more than just a temple, it's a place where history, literature, and spirituality converge. As I walked through its serene premises, I was struck by the white marble walls engraved with verses from the Ramcharitmanas, the epic written by Goswami Tulsidas at this very site. It felt like stepping into a living manuscript.

One of the popular destinations in varanasi for d Turist & as well as for local people.
Full temple wall is curved with Sree Sree Tulsi das jis scripts .
Open prayer area inside the temple can mk ur mind clum & silent .
Garden is well maintained , several types of plants , flower increases the beauty of the temple .
Drinking water, toilet, seating area , walking lane in d temple garden make the place relaxing for Turist & devotees use to busy in reading the scripts in the temple wall .
This is an  unique temple in india dedicated to Sree Sree Tulsi das ji .

Anyone who love nature , who want to seat , who want to take rest in good environment, one who love Sanatan Dharma gonna love the temple üôè

No Entry Fee. Free entry .
Opening from 5 am to 9 pm everyday .
Although a modern structure but have all the Vibes of spirituality...
If you love walk, than this temple is in walking distance from Assi Ghat .
Just opposite of this temple one Hanuman temple is there , Bal Hanuman temple , visit that temple tooo.

It's a temple dedicated to Santh Tulasi Das. There are idols of Lord Ram, Lakshman and Maa Sita. A museum is also present at the top floor of the temple and it costs only INR 50 per person for getting entry to the museum. The museum offers a great display of illustrations of different kathas present in Ramayan through different idols. You can see the pictures I have added here.

A must visit devotional site comes midway of your way to the Sankat Mochan Hanuman temple!!

places.address: Sankat Mochan Rd, Durgakund Rd, near Jalan, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221005, India

sources.snippet: Returning to the bank of the Ganges, we will find the temple dedicated to Vishalakshi. Unlike the other temples we visited in this review earlier, this one has a South Indian style. In this way, the temple stands with unique architecture in Varanasi.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Varanasi for Travelling Architect

places.name: Shri Vishalakshi Mata Shaktipeeth Temple, Kashi

reviews.text:
Though it is one of the Shakthi peetam of Maa Durga‚Ä¶. The temple is very simple.
I visited the temple in last hours and participated in the last Harathi of the day. Blessed to be one of the four devotees present in the ritual.
Had a great Darshana and offered Prasadam by the pandit, placed at the foot of the Maa Visaalaakahi.
I'm the busy and narrow streets of Kashi the night Aarthi is quite different.

This temple is the back of kashi vishwanath temple. One has to go here through street no. 2 godowlia. 10 min walking distance from kashi vishvnath temple.
It's in a busy and narrow street.
Many people don't know about this Shaktipeeth.
It's a small temple.
it's dedicated to Goddess Vishalakshi, an aspect of Goddess Parvati. Vishalakshi  temple is believed to be the spot where Sati's earrings fell. It's a  significant pilgrimage site for Hindus.
Photo here is not allowed.
Must visit place.

üî± Jai Maa Vishalakshi! üî±

üå∏ Shri Vishalakshi Mata Shaktipeeth Temple: A Divine Gem Often Overlooked in Kashi üå∏

Tucked away in the sacred lanes of Kashi lies one of the most powerful yet often missed temples; Shri Vishalakshi Mata Shaktipeeth. While millions come to Kashi for darshan of Baba Vishwanath, many remain unaware that Maa Vishalakshi, one of the 51 Shaktipeethas, resides just nearby, radiating immense spiritual energy and motherly compassion.

This temple holds immense significance, it is believed to be the sacred spot where Maa Sati's earrings (kundal) fell, making it a spiritually charged site where Shakti and Shiva dwell in eternal union. For seekers of Shakti (divine feminine energy) and inner awakening, this temple is a must-visit.

Despite its spiritual power, it often remains out of the typical pilgrimage itinerary. But once you enter the serene sanctum and gaze upon Maa Vishalakshi's murti adorned in vibrant sarees and flowers, you will feel an instant connection, as if a mother is embracing her child.

üõï Temple Tips:

It's just a short walk from Kashi Vishwanath Temple and Manikarnika Ghat.

The temple is peaceful and less crowded, making it perfect for quiet devotion.

Devotees often offer sarees, bangles, and sindoor to the Devi.

If you're visiting Kashi, don't miss this sacred jewel. Your spiritual journey will feel incomplete without seeking the blessings of Maa Vishalakshi, the all-seeing, all-loving Mother of Kashi.

üî± Jai Maa Vishalakshi! üî±

places.address: Shri Kashi Vishalakshi Mata Shaktipeeth Temple, Kashi Lahori Tola Near Ganpati Guest House Meer Ghat, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

places.generalDescription: Sankat Mochan Hanuman Mandir, located on the serene banks of River Assi in Varanasi, is a sacred temple dedicated to Lord Hanuman. Established by Saint Sri Goswami Tulsidas in the early 1500s after a divine vision, it is believed that worshipping here can relieve devotees from various troubles and appease those suffering from shani dosh.

sources.snippet: We mentioned that Goswami Tulsidas wrote his Ramcharitmanas on the site where the Tulsi Manas Temple stands today. The Hindu poet and saint supposedly had a vision of the divinity and vanara Hanuman at the site where today we find the Sankat Mochan Hanuman Temple. This place of worship, much simpler and smaller than those described above, will give us an idea of ‚Äã‚Äãhow spirituality in architecture is not always achieved with great gestures and resources, but on the contrary, with the transmission of sensations and sensuality in its spatiality.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Varanasi for Travelling Architect

places.name: Sankat Mochan Hanuman Temple, Varanasi

reviews.text: The Sankat Mochan Hanuman temple is a very old and important temple in India, believed to be around 400 years old. It is said Goswami Tulsidas Ji, who wrote Ramcharitmanas, built it sometime between 1631 and 1680. It is believed Hanuman Ji himself inspired Tulsidas Ji when he was writing RamCharitmanas, and that Tulsidas Ji even met Hanuman Ji at this very place. Hanuman Ji is present here in the form of Soil( Mitti). Devotees believe that just by visiting the temple and seeing the statue of Hanuman Ji, their problems will be solved. Every year, on a specific day (Kartik Krishna Chaturdashi), a special morning prayer is held. Special prayers and events are also held during Ramnavmi, Diwali and Hanuman Jayanti. The temple has a small museum to learn about Hanuman Ji. The temple also does charity work helping orphans and poor families. The temple has tight security, and no phones are allowed inside. When we went, it was very crowded because of Kumbh Mela in Prayagraj. People were slowly moving in line, chanting "Jai Hanuman." It was all very peaceful and spiritual. Across from this temple is another temple for Sri Ram Ji,Devi Sita and Lakshman Ji. Hanuman Ji's statue faces them directly. Near the entrance, shops sell sweets and offerings for Hanuman Ji like Besan Laddu, Sindoor & Yellow dress. There is parking for bikes in front of the main Gate, but cars have to park elsewhere. There are lockers for phones and electronics. You can leave your shoes outside or at a shop where you buy offerings. This temple is a must-see in Varanasi, along with other famous temples like Kashi Vishwanath and Kaal Bhairav.

Sankat Mochan Hanuman Temple, Varanasi ‚Äì A Spiritual Oasis

Visiting the Sankat Mochan Hanuman Temple in Varanasi is a deeply spiritual and uplifting experience. Dedicated to Lord Hanuman, the temple is renowned for its powerful energy and the belief that it helps devotees overcome troubles and obstacles, living up to its name-Sankat Mochan, which means ‚Äúreliever of troubles.‚Äù

The temple's architecture is simple yet captivating, reflecting the devotion and faith of countless visitors who come here daily. The vibrant atmosphere during the morning and evening aarti (prayer ceremony) is mesmerizing, with chants, hymns, and ringing bells creating a sense of peace and reverence.

One of the most remarkable aspects is the temple's accessibility; it welcomes people from all walks of life, fostering a spirit of inclusivity and community. The priests are friendly and often eager to explain the significance of the rituals to first-time visitors, which adds to the enriching experience.

Located slightly away from the bustling main ghats of Varanasi, the temple offers a quiet sanctuary amidst the city's vibrant chaos. Whether you are a devotee or a curious traveler, the Sankat Mochan Hanuman Temple promises a moment of calm, faith, and reflection, making it a must-visit landmark in Varanasi.

Sankat Mochan Mandir in Varanasi is one of the most sacred and peaceful temples dedicated to Lord Hanuman. The temple holds deep spiritual significance, as it is believed that visiting here removes all obstacles and fulfills wishes. The atmosphere is filled with devotion, with continuous chanting of Hanuman Chalisa creating a divine vibration.

The temple is well-maintained, clean, and organized despite the constant flow of devotees. Even during rush hours, the darshan usually happens smoothly. The prasad, especially the famous besan laddoo, is a highlight and loved by devotees. The surroundings are calm, with ample space to sit and pray.

Located near BHU, the temple is easily accessible and has a strong spiritual aura that instantly brings peace of mind. For anyone visiting Varanasi, Sankat Mochan Mandir is a must-visit, not just for its religious importance but also for the positivity and serenity it offers.
No phones allowed!

places.address: Saket Nagar Colony, Sankata Mochan Leprosy, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221005, India

places.generalDescription: Ratneshwar Mahadev Temple, also known as the Leaning Temple of Varanasi, is a unique and intriguing site located at Manikarnika Ghat in the holy city of Varanasi, India. This temple stands out due to its distinctive leaning structure, with a significant tilt towards the northwest.

sources.snippet: Known as Ratneshwar Mahadev Mandir it is one of the most photographed temples of Varanasi. It is built in the classical style of temple architecture with nagara shikhara. It leans at least 9 degrees towards the north-west side.
sources.shortName: Architecture of Indian Cities: Varanasi- Beyond being the spiritual Capital of India - RTF

places.name: Ratneshwar Mahadev Temple

reviews.text:
"Ratneshwar Mahadev Temple - The Leaning Marvel of Varanasi"
The Ratneshwar Mahadev Temple, famously known as the "Leaning Temple of Varanasi," is an architectural wonder situated near Manikarnika Ghat. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, this temple stands out with its noticeable tilt, adding a mysterious charm to its historical and spiritual significance.

Surrounded by the serene Ganges, the temple becomes partially submerged during the monsoon, making it even more captivating. While you can't always enter the temple, its unique design and setting make it a must-see landmark for history lovers, photographers, and devotees alike.

A visit to this temple offers a glimpse into Varanasi's rich heritage, blending spirituality and architectural intrigue.

Ratneshwar Mahadev Temple is a serene and divine place to visit. The atmosphere here is very calming, and the temple is beautifully maintained. Surrounded by nature, it's a great spot to sit, relax, and connect spiritually. Whether you're visiting for devotion or just to enjoy the peaceful vibes, it's definitely worth a visit. A must-see for those who appreciate quiet and sacred spaces.

Rameshwar mahadev is situated near to manikarnika ghat.
Its widely known as the leaning temple of Varanasi.
Dedicated to lord shiva this temple is self-originitated ( swayambhu),
It's of great religious and historical significance.
There is no entry ticket.
During the monsoon or flood conditions the temple is merged in the water.
its unique design and setting make it a must-see landmark for history lovers, photographers, and devotees alike.

A visit to this temple offers a glimpse into Varanasi's rich heritage, blending spirituality and architectural intrigue

places.address: Ratneshwar Mahadev, Manikarnika Ghat, next to cremation Ground, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

places.generalDescription: Anup Architects is an architectural and interior design firm that specializes in land use and site master planning, value engineering, construction administration. They have a proven track record of completing projects on budget and on schedule.

sources.siteName: NearMeTrade ‚Äì Local and Global Products, Services, Manufacturers & Exporters.
sources.shortName: 100 Best Architects in Varanasi Uttar Pradesh

places.name: Anup Architect & Associates

reviews.text: I had the pleasure of working with Anup Architect & Associates, and I can confidently say they are the best architect in Varanasi. Their creativity, attention to detail, and dedication to bringing our vision to life were remarkable. From the initial consultation to the final design, their team was professional, responsive, and truly understood our needs. They balanced aesthetics and functionality perfectly, and the result exceeded our expectations. If you're looking for top-notch architectural services in Varanasi, I highly recommend Anup Architect & Associates!

Anup Architect and Associates truly stand out as the best architect in Varanasi, delivering innovative designs with exceptional attention to detail. Their professionalism and commitment to client satisfaction make them a top choice for any architectural project.

Anup architect and Associates is truly the best in Varanasi! Their innovative designs and attention to detail transformed our vision into reality, creating a stunning space that perfectly blends functionality. ‚ò∫ Highly recommended for anyone looking to start their projects!

places.address: 174, Lane no. 7 Janki Nagar Colony, Bari, Badi Patiya Rd, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221109, India

places.generalDescription: Manikarnika Ghat is a significant site in Varanasi, where cremation ceremonies take place. It's a place of spiritual importance along with other ghats like Assi Ghat, Dashashwamedh Ghat, Shivala Ghat, and Ahilyabai Ghat. Panchganga Ghat is where five rivers converge and Kashi Vishwanath Temple houses the only Jyotirlinga in Uttar Pradesh.

sources.snippet: Manikarnika Ghat is known not only for 24√ó7 burning fire but also for its tilted temple. Known as Ratneshwar Mahadev Mandir it is one of the most photographed temples of Varanasi. It is built in the classical style of temple architecture with nagara shikhara.
sources.shortName: Architecture of Indian Cities: Varanasi- Beyond being the spiritual Capital of India - RTF

places.name: Manikarnika Ghat

reviews.text: Manikarnika Ghat in Varanasi is one of the most sacred cremation sites along the Ganges River, steeped in spiritual significance and vibrant rituals. Visitors can witness the profound cultural heritage and the poignant beauty of life and death interwoven in this timeless location. It's a must-visit for those seeking an authentic experience of Varanasi's rich traditions.

I had heard a lot about Manikarnika Ghat. You will come here and get to know the truth of life.
You will find many boats for boating here. You can worship and take a bath here. There is a temple nearby, you can visit it...

All the shopkeeper, Pandits and bostman who are earning from tourists  There should be pay attention to cleanliness ... and also  The responsibility of the tourist to clean the tourist place

I had heard a lot about Manikarnika Ghat. You will come here and get to know the truth of life.

You will find many boats for boating here. You can worship and take a bath here. There is a temple nearby, you can visit it.

places.address: near Lalita Ghat, Lahori Tola, Varanasi, Domari, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

places.generalDescription: Man Mandir Ghat, also known as Someshwara Ghat, is a stunning ancient ghat in Varanasi with remarkable Rajput architecture. Built over 400 years ago by Maharaja Man Singh, it features an impressive palace adorned with intricate carvings and stone balconies. The addition of the Jantar Mantar observatory by Sawai Jai Singh II in the 1730s adds a scientific dimension to the ghat.

sources.snippet: Man Mandir Ghat: This ghat is named after the King Sawai Man Singh of Amber (in Rajasthan), who built a magnificent building with exquisite, ornately carved window carvings. The porches and windows of the palace are excellent example of medieval period Rajput and Durg styles.

places.name: Man Mandir Ghat

reviews.text:
Man Mandir Ghat, originally known as Someshwar Ghat, holds a rich history. It was built by Raja Man Singh of Amer in the 16th century, and the palace that stands on it is a beautiful example of Rajput-Mughal architecture. The ghat itself, with its broad stone steps, offers a tranquil space for pilgrims and visitors to connect with the holy Ganges River.
‚ÄãThe site is also a place of great scientific importance. Perched on top of the palace is an astronomical observatory, which was constructed by Raja Jai Singh II, a descendant of Raja Man Singh. This observatory, often referred to as Jantar Mantar, houses various masonry instruments designed to measure time and study celestial bodies.
‚ÄãThe Man Mandir Palace and its ghat are a visual spectacle, especially at night when the stone facade is illuminated, reflecting a serene glow on the river. The intricately carved windows and balconies, or jharokhas, add to the architectural grandeur. A stroll here provides a peaceful escape from the bustle of the city.
‚ÄãIn conclusion, Man Mandir Ghat is more than just a place for ritual bathing. It's a blend of spiritual devotion, architectural excellence, and scientific history. The palace and observatory stand as silent witnesses to centuries of tradition and innovation, making it a truly unique and enriching destination.

Raja Mansingh, the King of Amer in the 16th century, built the Ghat, along with a palace and a temple at the site. The Ghat is named after his surname, becoming known as Man Temple Ghat. In 1831, it was first mentioned by James Prinsep. Before that, it was called Someshwar Ghat until the 18th century.

This Ghat is notable for its large artistic palace and a place called Nakshatra Vaidhshala, which has both religious and cultural importance. The palace showcases the architectural styles of the Mathura Govardhan temple and the Rajasthani Rajput style from the North Medieval Period.

Raja Sawai Jai Singh, a descendant of Raja Mansingh, established the Nakshatra Vaidhshala in the 17th century, with plans made by a famous astrologer named Samrath Jagannath. Various astrological instruments, like Samrat Yantra and Naadi Valay Yantra, can be found in the Vaidhshala.

Man Mandir Ghat in Varanasi is a historically and architecturally significant site, well-regarded for its beautiful views of the Ganges and its historical structures. Built by Maharaja Man Singh of Amer in 1600 AD, the ghat features the Man Singh Observatory, also known as Jantar Mantar, which was added by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II in 1710 AD. This observatory remains a fascinating spot for visitors despite its deteriorating condition. The ghat is renowned for its serene atmosphere, particularly during sunrise and sunset, making it an ideal place for photography and boat rides.

places.address: D31/178, Dashashwamedh Ghat Rd, Bhairavi ghat, Bangali Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

sources.snippet: With this status of being used often as an adjective, synonymous with liberation another popular phrase is Karvat Kashi also known as the final sleep. It is a belief that people travel here from far off places to finally end their lives, in the Karvat Kashi temple located in the vicinity of the Vishwanath temple complex. However, in recent times the term Karvat Kashi has been used popularly to describe a bent temple (Karvat, meaning bent) located on the Ghats.
sources.shortName: Architecture of Kashi | Architecture of Varanasi

places.name: Sri Kashi Karvat Mandir

reviews.text:
Shri Kashi Karvat Mandir is a testimony of how far people went to attain Mukti.
It is believed that earlier there was a saw  near the Shivlinga which was used to cut people's head into two. This process was done to attain Mukti.

However the location shown on Google is Wrong! The temple is near Kashi Viswanath.

The Kashi Karvat Mandir is a unique and fascinating temple located near the Kashi Vishwanath Temple on the banks of the Ganges River. This ancient temple is famous for its unusual feature: it leans at an angle of about 9 degrees!

Over the centuries, the temple has experienced the effects of the river's changing water levels. During times of high water, the temple has even been partially submerged.

This leaning temple is a must-see when visiting Varanasi. It's a reminder of the city's long and complex history and the powerful forces of nature.

This location is wrong. Kashi Karvat Mandir is not on the banks of Ganga. Someone please update the correct location. When I visited the temple in 2023, google showed the correct location which is in Govindpur but now in 2024 it is showing a completely different location on the river bank.

places.address: 31/30, Nepali Khapra, Ghats of Varanasi, Katesar, Varanasi, Domari, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

places.generalDescription: Chet Singh Fort, a remarkable historical site nestled along the banks of the Ganges River in Varanasi, is steeped in rich heritage. Named after Maharaja Chet Singh, who constructed it in the 18th century, this fort witnessed a significant battle against British forces led by Warren Hastings in 1781. Although visitors can't explore its interior, they can enjoy breathtaking views from its steps and relax at the adjacent ghat.

sources.snippet: Chet Singh Fort: This ghat derived its name from Maharaja Chet Singh of Banaras. A fort-cum-old palatial building is there on the river bank. This fort witnessed a fierce battle between the troops of Maharaja Chet Singh and Warren Hestings in 1781, that resulted to the defeat of Chet Singh.

places.name: Chet Singh Fort

reviews.text: This is Chet Singh Fort if you come to see Morning Arti in Assi Ghat then you must Vist this Fort it is located near Asi Ghat.
It's a beautiful exterior of the fort.. you're not allowed to go inside but you can relax on the steps of the ghat or the fort

Chet Singh Fort, located near the iconic ghats of Varanasi, is a historic landmark that stands as a testament to the city's rich cultural and political past. Built by Maharaja Chet Singh in the 18th century, the fort played a crucial role during his resistance against British forces, making it a site of historical significance.

Perched along the Ganges River, the fort offers stunning views of the river and its surrounding ghats, making it a picturesque destination for visitors. Though much of the structure is now in ruins, the remnants of its walls, gates, and courtyards evoke a sense of grandeur and resilience. The fort's architecture reflects a blend of Mughal and Rajput styles, adding to its historical charm.

The fort is a relatively quiet spot compared to the bustling ghats, providing a peaceful escape for those seeking to explore Varanasi's less commercialized sites. It is an ideal place for history enthusiasts, photographers, and those who enjoy exploring offbeat locations.

However, the fort suffers from neglect, with limited restoration and maintenance efforts. Lack of proper signage and information about its history can leave visitors feeling underwhelmed. Additionally, there are occasional complaints about litter and poor upkeep in the area.

Despite these shortcomings, Chet Singh Fort remains a must-visit for those interested in Varanasi's history and culture. Its scenic location and historical importance make it a hidden gem that deserves more attention and care from both authorities and visitors.

places.address: 72V4+MRC, Ghats of Varanasi, Ghasi Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

places.generalDescription: Bharat Kala Bhavan Museum, located within the Banaras Hindu University, is a treasure trove of art and culture. The museum showcases a diverse collection of sculptures, paintings, jewelry, textiles, and more, offering visitors a comprehensive look into India's rich artistic and archaeological heritage. As one of the key attractions in Varanasi, the museum provides an immersive experience for those interested in delving into the city's cultural tapestry.

sources.snippet: Built in 1962, it is a clear exponent of architectural eclecticism, taking styles, pieces, and meanings from different styles and periods. Close to the University of Varanasi, it has multiple galleries with temporary and permanent exhibitions. Within the permanent collection, we will find more than one hundred thousand pieces, such as books, manuscripts, sculptures, paintings, and all kinds of artifacts from the history of India, Buddhism, and Hinduism.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Varanasi for Travelling Architect

places.name: Bharat Kala Bhavan Museum, BHU Varanasi

reviews.text:
Bharat Kala Bhavan, located within the prestigious Banaras Hindu University (BHU) campus in Varanasi, is a treasure trove of art, culture, and history. Established in 1920, this museum is one of the finest in India, showcasing a remarkable collection of artifacts, paintings, sculptures, textiles, and historical objects that reflect India's rich cultural heritage.

The museum is divided into several galleries, each dedicated to a specific theme or era. The **Indian Miniature Paintings Gallery** is a standout, featuring exquisite works from the Mughal, Rajput, and Pahari schools. The **Sculpture Gallery** houses ancient and medieval sculptures, including rare pieces from the Gupta and Kushan periods. The **Textile Gallery** displays a stunning array of traditional Indian fabrics, including Banarasi silk, which Varanasi is famous for.

One of the highlights of Bharat Kala Bhavan is the **Nicholas Roerich Gallery**, which showcases the works of the renowned Russian artist who was deeply influenced by Indian culture and spirituality. The museum also has a fascinating collection of historical artifacts, including coins, manuscripts, and decorative arts.

The museum is well-maintained, with informative plaques and descriptions accompanying each exhibit. The staff is knowledgeable and eager to assist visitors, making the experience even more enriching. The serene environment of the BHU campus adds to the charm of the visit.

Bharat Kala Bhavan is a must-visit for art lovers, history buffs, and anyone interested in exploring India's cultural legacy. The entry fee is nominal, and the museum is easily accessible within the BHU campus.

The display of miniature paintings, terracotta art, and Buddhist artifacts stood out the most. The staff was polite and helpful, guiding us to explore different galleries Kala Bhawan is not just a museum but a treasure house of knowledge and creativity. It is a must-visit for students, researchers, and anyone interested in Indian art and history. The experience was inspiring and left me with a deeper appreciation of our cultural roots.

A very peaceful place . Bharat Kala Bhawan is truly one of the gems inside Banaras Hindu University. It is not just a museum but a journey through India's history, culture, and art. The collection is vast and diverse - from ancient sculptures, coins, and terracotta pieces to exquisite miniature paintings and textiles. What I loved the most was how beautifully the museum preserves the essence of India's heritage in one place.

The galleries are well-organized, and each section has detailed information that makes it easier to understand the historical importance of the artifacts. The miniature painting section, in particular, is mesmerizing - it feels like stepping back into the Mughal and Rajput eras.

Another special aspect is the connection of Bharat Kala Bhawan with Banaras itself. Many exhibits reflect the cultural richness of Varanasi, its traditions, and its role as a living museum of Indian heritage.

Overall, my visit was enriching and peaceful. It's a must-visit for students, researchers, or anyone interested in art and history. The museum is not too crowded, which makes it easy to explore at your own pace.

‚≠ê Rating: 4.5/5 - A beautiful treasure house of Indian culture worth visiting at least once!

places.address: Banaras Hindu University, Semi Circle Road No. 3 Opp Institute of Mgmt Studies, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221005, India
